content.raw: @scpeters and @rosebudflyaway, do you have any suggestions for a scenario that would show the differences between two difference physics profiles (world vs. quickstep, for example)?
content.html: @scpeters and @rosebudflyaway, do you have any suggestions for a scenario that would show the differences between two difference physics profiles (world vs. quickstep, for example)?

content.raw:
An obvious one is changing `real_time_update_rate` between `real-time` (update_rate = 1 / dt) and `slow motion`, which just has a reduced update rate. I often do this to observe transient effects.

A more dramatic example is the [inertia_ratio_pendulum world](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/9c10e12654f7013bd4c32854b95c4535e3d47210/test/worlds/inertia_ratio_pendulum.world?at=default#), which has a double pendulum attached to the world. The middle link is much smaller, and there is a large inertia ratio between the two links of the pendulum (shown in image).

![inertia_ratio_pendulum](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/96660379/inertia_ratio_pendulum.svg)

The large inertia ratio causes the ODE quickstep constraint solver (based on the iterative Projected Gauss Seidel method) to converge slowly. To illustrate the convergence problems, a lateral gravity force is applied (parallel to joint axes). This causes wobbling behavior. That world defaults to quickstep with 250 iterations and lateral gravity (g_x) of 0.1 m/s^2. Increasing the gravity to 1.0 m/s^2 makes the wobbling much more visible. Re-running the simulation with the ODE `world` solver (based on a pivoting rather than iterative method) shows that much larger gravity values can be tolerated by the pivoting solver.
content.html:
An obvious one is changing real_time_update_rate between real-time (update_rate = 1 / dt) and slow motion, which just has a reduced update rate. I often do this to observe transient effects.

A more dramatic example is the inertia_ratio_pendulum world, which has a double pendulum attached to the world. The middle link is much smaller, and there is a large inertia ratio between the two links of the pendulum (shown in image).

The large inertia ratio causes the ODE quickstep constraint solver (based on the iterative Projected Gauss Seidel method) to converge slowly. To illustrate the convergence problems, a lateral gravity force is applied (parallel to joint axes). This causes wobbling behavior. That world defaults to quickstep with 250 iterations and lateral gravity (g_x) of 0.1 m/s^2. Increasing the gravity to 1.0 m/s^2 makes the wobbling much more visible. Re-running the simulation with the ODE world solver (based on a pivoting rather than iterative method) shows that much larger gravity values can be tolerated by the pivoting solver.

content.raw:
My attempts to incorporate this phenomenon as an example in this world led me to discover a bug where PresetManager was not setting the solver type of the profile. This is because the SDF element is called `type` and the representation in `ODEPhysics` is `solver_type`, so the key read from SDF did not get recognized.

However, it appears that we still can't set the solver type of ODE during runtime because the solver does not get dynamically recreated when the solver type gets updated.

Therefore I have two physics profiles in a world with the model Steve linked to. Both use the quickstep solver but one increases the iterations by a lot so that the behavior of the pendulum is stable for this profile.

@\_jrivero\_, can you run the new example and let me know what you think?
content.html:
My attempts to incorporate this phenomenon as an example in this world led me to discover a bug where PresetManager was not setting the solver type of the profile. This is because the SDF element is called type and the representation in ODEPhysics is solver_type, so the key read from SDF did not get recognized.

However, it appears that we still can't set the solver type of ODE during runtime because the solver does not get dynamically recreated when the solver type gets updated.

Therefore I have two physics profiles in a world with the model Steve linked to. Both use the quickstep solver but one increases the iterations by a lot so that the behavior of the pendulum is stable for this profile.

@_jrivero_, can you run the new example and let me know what you think?

content.raw:
Not sure if I'm misunderstanding, but this snippet is just showing some of the functions which can be used, but not in an way a user would generally want to do it, right? What do you think of separating them into smaller snippets, for example, "*You can create an empty profile like this, and you can put it in an if block to catch an error*" then the snippet, then more text "*You can set parameters for the current profile, or for any of the existing profiles. Here the functions also return a boolean for optional error-checking*." And so on... Or if you want to keep it all in one snippet, how about adding more comments?

Another thing which made me confused, maybe because of the overlapping names, was whether the snippet would be overwriting the profiles set in the SDF. Because I assume once you load the world, above, these profiles are already set, right? I guess you are showing an alternative way of doing it, but I just got confused for a second...

And finally, you mentioned it would "generate an SDF element", but I'm not sure where that's being done. Is there a function which returns a pointer?
content.html:
Not sure if I'm misunderstanding, but this snippet is just showing some of the functions which can be used, but not in an way a user would generally want to do it, right? What do you think of separating them into smaller snippets, for example, "You can create an empty profile like this, and you can put it in an if block to catch an error" then the snippet, then more text "You can set parameters for the current profile, or for any of the existing profiles. Here the functions also return a boolean for optional error-checking." And so on... Or if you want to keep it all in one snippet, how about adding more comments?

Another thing which made me confused, maybe because of the overlapping names, was whether the snippet would be overwriting the profiles set in the SDF. Because I assume once you load the world, above, these profiles are already set, right? I guess you are showing an alternative way of doing it, but I just got confused for a second...

And finally, you mentioned it would "generate an SDF element", but I'm not sure where that's being done. Is there a function which returns a pointer?
